case_name: Union of India v. Capt. S. K. Rao

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1653 of 1967 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated February 23, 1967 of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 403-D of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1653 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 23, 1967 Of the Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 403-D of 1959.

facts.text: The matter was heard formally on November 19, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: We beard the matter formally again on November 19, 1971. We adopt the judgment as our own.

facts.text: This is an appeal by the Union of India by way of special leave.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the Union of India by way of special leave.

facts.text: On April 9, 1959, the Central Government directed removal from service of Capt. S. K. Rao under r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On April 9, 1959, the Central Government directed removal from service of Capt. S. K. Rao under r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

facts.text: Rao was a commissioned officer in the Indian Army and was attached to the Army Ordnance Corps Training Centre, Secundrabad.

anchor.surface_text: Rao was a companymissioned officer in the Indian Army and was attached to the Army Ordnance Corps Training Centre, Secundrabad.

facts.text: On April 4, 1958, Rao committed acts of gross misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that on April 4, 1958, he companymitted acts of .gross misconduct.

facts.text: Rao assisted Kumari Prakash, daughter of a brother officer, in going away from her parents protection and planning to run away with a sepoy.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations were as follows Knowing Kumari Prakash as the daughter of a brother Officer, Rao assisted her in going away from her parents protection and planning to run away with a sepoy.

facts.text: Rao threatened to cause harm to Kumari Prakash's parents and intimidated her to visit his house.

anchor.surface_text: Rao, by threatening to cause harm to Kumari Prakashs parents, intimidated her t o visit his house where he took her in his scooter to the unit lines of 51 1 1 Gurkha Rifles

facts.text: Rao took Kumari Prakash in his scooter to the unit lines of 51 Gurkha Rifles and arranged her meeting with a sepoy.

anchor.surface_text: where he took her in his scooter to the unit lines of 51 1 1 Gurkha Rifles where he arranged her meeting with a sepoy of the unit.

facts.text: Rao acquiesced in the girl being met by the sepoy at a tea shop nearby where she received a present of a sari and blouse from the sepoy in his presence.

anchor.surface_text: He  i.e. Rao  acquiesced in the girl being met by the sepoy later at a tea shop nearby where she received a present of a sari and blouse from the sepoy in his presence.

facts.text: Rao actively abetted the attempt of brother officer's daughter to elope with a sepoy.

anchor.surface_text: Rao thus actively abetted in the attempt of brother officers daughter elope with a sepoy.

facts.text: Rao took Kumari Prakash to a hotel Saidya Lodge in Hyderabad and got a room by impersonating as Mr. Mrs. Prakash.

anchor.surface_text: Rao then took Kumari Prakash to a hotel Saidya Lodge in Hyderabad and got a room to themselves by impersonating and giving a false identity as Mr. Mrs. Prakash.

facts.text: An inquiry into the matter was made by Court of Inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: An inquiry into the matter was made by Court of Inquiry.

facts.text: The Chief of the Army Staff considered the conduct of Capt. Rao most unbecoming of an officer after going through the proceedings of the Court of Inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief of the Army Staff, after going through the proceedings of the Court of Inquiry, companysidered that the companyduct of Capt. Rao was most unbecoming of an officer.

facts.text: Chief of Army Staff ordered administrative action under r. 14 as trial by General Court Martial was inexpedient.

anchor.surface_text: As he was of opinion that trial of the officer by a General Court Martial was inexpedient, he ordered administrative action to be taken under r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

facts.text: By memorandum dated September 4, 1958, Rao was called upon to submit his explanation regarding the allegations.

anchor.surface_text: By memorandum dated September 4, 1958, Rao was called upon to submit his explanation by way of defence regarding the allegations against him.

facts.text: The explanation of Rao was placed before the Central Government and found to be unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation of Rao was placed before the Central Government. The Central Government found it to be unsatisfactory,

facts.text: Capt. Rao filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of removal from service.

anchor.surface_text: Capt. Rao thereupon filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of removal from service

facts.text: Rao claimed in the petition that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and action was without authority.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground, inter alia, that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and that the action taken thereunder was without any authority.

facts.text: In the petition, Rao stated he did not assist Kumari Prakash to go away from her parents house.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition Rao gave a somewhat different version of what had happened. According to him he did number assist Kumari Prakash to go away from her parents house.

facts.text: At the hearing of the petition, the only point urged was the validity of r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the petition the only point which was urged was the validity of r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

facts.text: The Army Rules, 1954, including r. 14, were framed under s. 191 of the Army Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Army Rules, 1954, including r. 14, were framed in exer- cise of the powers companyferred by s. 191 of the Army Act, 1950.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed without order as to costs and the case will not go back to the High Court for disposal on merits on other questions raised by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed but in the circumstances of the case without any order as to companyts. The case will number go back to the High Court for disposal on merits on the other questions raised by the respondent herein in the High Court.
This is an appeal by the Union of India by way of special leave.
Art. 226
On April 9, 1959, the Central Government directed removal from service of Capt. S. K. Rao under r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

concepts.interpretation: Valid rule for administrative removal without court-martial when retention undesirable, after notice and explanation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: erefore, number ultra vires. It was argued that the words subject to the provisions of this Act occurring in s. 19 makes s. 19 subject to s. 45, and t

concepts.unlisted_description: Provides procedure for communicating views on misconduct, calling for explanation, and recommending dismissal/removal/retirement/resignation.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, is as follows When after companysidering the reports on an officers misconduct, the Central Gove rnment is satisfied or the C-in-C is of the opinion, that the trial of the officer by a companyrt- martial is inexpedient or impracticable but companysiders the further retention of the said officer in the service as undesirable, the C- in-C shall companymunicate the view of the Central Government or his views, as the case may be, to the officer together with all reports adverse to him and he shall be called upon to submit his explanation and defence.

concepts.unlisted_description: Full text of the rule quoted.

anchor.surface_text: The Army Rules, 1954, including r. 14, were framed in exer- cise of the powers companyferred by s. 191 of the Army Act, 1950.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers making rules including for removal, retirement etc. of persons subject to the Act.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: and defence. If the explanation is found to be unsatisfactory, the Central Government has been given the power to dismiss or remove the officer. Rules

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to make rules, specifically sub-s(2)(a) for removal etc.

anchor.surface_text: S.18--Every person subject to this Act shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.

concepts.unlisted_description: Officers hold office during pleasure of President.

anchor.surface_text: s. 19--Subject to the provisions of this Act and the rules and regulations made thereunder the Central Government may dismiss, or remove from the service, any person subject to this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Independent power to dismiss/remove, subject to Act and rules, not requiring court-martial.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: cally gives. power to make a rule providing for the removal from the service of persons subject to the Act. It follows that there may be a valid rule

concepts.unlisted_description: Central Government power to dismiss or remove persons subject to Act.

anchor.surface_text: S. 45-Any officer, junior companymissioned officer or warrant officer who behaves in a manner unbecoming his position and the character expected of him shall, on companyviction by companyrt-martial, if he is an officer, be liable to be cashiered or to suffer such less punishment as is in this Act mentioned

concepts.interpretation: Applies only on conviction by court-martial; mutually exclusive from administrative removal under s.19 and r.14.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rring in s. 19 makes s. 19 subject to s. 45, and the Central Government has thus numberpower to remove a person from the service in derogation of the

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for unbecoming conduct on court-martial conviction.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground, inter alia, that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and that the action taken thereunder was without any authority.

concepts.interpretation: Rejected; r.14 held intra vires as authorized by s.191(2)(a) and consistent with s.19.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: should be rules, and subject to the provisions of the Act and such rules, the Central Government may dismiss or remove from the service any person su

concepts.unlisted_description: Argument that subordinate legislation exceeds enabling statute.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 18 19 which appear in Ch. IV of the Army Act dealing with Conditions of Service
Offenses under the Army Act have been dealt with in ss. 34 to 70 in Ch. VI,

issues.text: whether r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and whether the action taken thereunder was without any authority

anchor.surface_text: on the ground, inter alia, that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and that the action taken thereunder was without any authority.

issues.text: the validity of r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the petition the only point which was urged was the validity of r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954.

issues.text: Whether giving power to the Central Government to remove an officer without being tried and convicted by court-martial was in derogation of s. 45 of the Army Act making Rule 14 ultra vires
Whether the words 'subject to the provisions of this Act' in s. 19 make s. 19 subject to s. 45 such that the Central Government has no power to remove a person from service in derogation of s. 45

arguments.claim: r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and that the action taken thereunder was without any authority

anchor.surface_text: on the ground, inter alia, that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, was ultra vires the Army Act, 1950, and that the action taken thereunder was without any authority.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: should be rules, and subject to the provisions of the Act and such rules, the Central Government may dismiss or remove from the service any person su

arguments.court_reasoning: r.14 intra vires s.191(2)(a), consistent with s.19; s.19 and s.45 mutually exclusive

arguments.claim: the Army Act contained specific provisions for punishment for unbecoming conduct, viz. s. 45; giving power to Central Government to remove without court-martial derogates s.45 making r.14 ultra vires
arguments.court_reasoning: s.19 suggests rules required; s.191(2)(a) empowers rules for removal; r.14 valid thereunder

arguments.claim: words 'subject to the provisions of this Act' in s.19 make s.19 subject to s.45 so Central Government has no power to remove in derogation of s.45
arguments.court_reasoning: s.19 independent power; s.19 and s.45 mutually exclusive; no court-martial needed for s.19+r.14 removal

arguments.claim: if r.14 intra vires Army Act, Rao has no case

anchor.surface_text: If this rule was intra vires the Army Act, Rao has no case.

arguments.claim: Army Rules including r.14 framed under s.191 Army Act; s.191(2)(a) empowers rules for removal/retirement etc. of persons subject to Act

anchor.surface_text: The Army Rules, 1954, including r. 14, were framed in exer- cise of the powers conferred by s. 191 of the Army Act, 1950. ... Sub-section 2 a provides Without prejudice to the generality of the power conferred by sub-section 1 , the rules made thereunder may provide for-- a the removal, retirement, release or discharge from the service of persons subject to this Act.

arguments.claim: s.19 requires rules; subject to Act and rules, Central Government may dismiss/remove any person subject to Act
there may be valid rule under s.191(2)(a) for removal subject to other Act provisions; r.14 is such rule, not ultra vires
power under s.19 independent; s.19 and s.45 mutually exclusive; no court-martial needed for removal under s.19 + r.14

holdings.text: Rule 14 of the Army Rules, 1954 is not ultra vires the Army Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The result is that r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, is number ultra vires the Army Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Framed under s.191(2)(a) empowering rules for removal; consistent with s.19 independent power; mutually exclusive from s.45 requiring court-martial

holdings.text: Rule 14 is intra vires as it is a valid rule under s.191(2)(a) for removal from service

anchor.surface_text: Section 191  2   a  specifically gives. power to make a rule providing for the removal from the service of persons subject to the Act. It follows that there may be a valid rule where under... Rule 14 is such a rule it is, therefore, number ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.191(2)(a) expressly provides for rules on removal, retirement etc.; Rule 14 fits this delegation

holdings.text: The power under s.19 is an independent power to remove without court-martial

anchor.surface_text: But the power under s. 19 is an independent power. Although s. 19 uses the words subject to the provisions of this Act, it speaks of removal of a person from the service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Subject to provisions of this Act' does not subordinate s.19 to s.45; s.19 contemplates rules for procedure

holdings.text: Sections 19 and 45 of the Army Act are mutually exclusive

anchor.surface_text: The two sections 19 and 45 of the Act are, therefore, mutually exclusive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.45 applies only on conviction by court-martial for cashiering; s.19 + r.14 for administrative removal without trial

holdings.text: Removal under s.19 read with r.14 does not require court-martial

anchor.surface_text: For removal from service under s. 19 of the Army Act read with r. 14 of the Army Rules, 1954, a companyrt-martial is number necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19 provides direct power subject to rules; r.14 supplies procedure after notice and unsatisfactory explanation

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the case remitted to the High Court for disposal on merits on other questions

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed but in the circumstances of the case without any order as to companyts. The case will number go back to the High Court for disposal on merits on the other questions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity point decided in favor of appellant; other issues raised by respondent not addressed by High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed but in the circumstances of the case without any order as to companyts. The case will number go back to the High Co

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Rule 14 of Army Rules, 1954 held not ultra vires Army Act; removal order upheld
directions: The case will not go back to the High Court for disposal on merits on the other questions raised by the respondent herein in the High Court
